results.title: Drought (D)
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall, Robert Loader and Golden Dolphin
results.brief_description: Powerful introduction to drought and other dramatic aspects of Australia’s climate, including bushfires, floods, cyclones. Examines how native plants and animals have adapted to these conditions, and looks at the history of European occupation. WARNING: Contains disturbing scenes of the agonising death of a herd of wild horses at a dry water hole and recommend viewing suitable for upper secondary student level only.

results.title: Dropping out: broken dreams
results.brief_description: This program teaches that education means options through the personal experiences of six adolescent students who have dropped out of school, experienced the realities of job hunting and decided for themselves that they need an education. This video is suitable for career studies and personal development and is relevant to the Australian situation.

results.title: Drop dead gorgeous
results.creator_credit: Michael Patrick Jann, Judy Hofflund, Gavin Polone, New Line Cinema, KC Medien and Capella
results.brief_description: Set in small town America, “Drop dead gorgeous” is a satire about teen beauty contests, ambitious parents and urban dysfunction. As the citizens of Mount Rose, Minnesota gear up for the Sarah Rose Miss Teen Princess America Pageant, the proceedings are filmed by a documentary crew, lending the film its mockumentary structure. The main contestants are Becky Leeman, whose ambitious mother runs the beauty contest and Amber Atkins, a plucky and talented working class teen who lives in a trailer park with her depressed alcoholic mother. When various contestants die in an array of mysterious circumstances Amber suspects that her life is in danger if she stays in competition. This film takes a savage view of American societal mores, as it mocks small town values, beauty contests, marriage, alcoholism, obesity, anorexia, paedophiles, handicapped people, mother-daughter relationships and the gauche self-consciousness of teenagers. It gladly follows in the footsteps of “Waiting for Guffman” and “Spinal tap”, but never reaches the hilarity of such predecessors, possibly due to its good natured and loveable heroine, contrasting too starkly with hideous caricatures. At times the black humour and merciless ridiculing of the screenplay are uncomfortable to watch, defiantly crossing over into bad taste on numerous occasions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Patrick Jann, Judy Hofflund, Gavin Polone, New Line Cinema, KC Medien and Capella

results.title: Driving: risks and responsibilities
results.brief_description: Cars have become an essential tool in most businesses and the risks and responsibilities associated with driving on the job are the primary focus of this program. Outlines the costs incurred to businesses when a car accident occurs, the benefits of a safe driving program and safe driving policy, as well as basic practices to ensure the safety of the driver, other road users, pedestrians and the car itself. Useful as a basic guide to vehicle safety for the instruction of new and learner drivers.

results.title: Driving without tears
results.creator_credit: Hector Lemieux, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: We accompany a driving instructor to see how the City of Vancouver trains expert and responsible motorists. Shows how a driving school gives both theoretical and practical teaching on all the intricacies of city and highway traffic. The film includes reference to training programs in secondary schools to make teenagers better drivers.

results.title: Driving to a system
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “How to Drive”.
The drills of the system of car control demonstrated have been well tried and are well proven; once memorised and understood, the system soon becomes an almost instinctive routine. The system is designed to ensure that at all times the car is in the right place on the road, travelling at the right speed for existing conditions, in the right gear, and the driver is never trying to do more than one thing at a time.

results.title: Driving Miss Daisy
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Lili Zanuck, Richard Zanuck, Warner Bros Pictures and Zanuck Company
results.brief_description: The funny, touching and totally irresistible story of a working relationship that became a twenty-five year friendship. When Daisy Werthan (Jessica Tandy) crashes her car, her son Boolie (Dan Ackroyd) insists that his mother’s driving days are over. He hires a chauffeur for her, Hoke Colburn (Morgan Freeman) to keep her out of trouble. But feisty Daisy resents the intrusion and she almost drives Hoke crazy with her insistence that she doesn’t need his help. Luckily, Hoke is a very patient man and the pair become the best of friends after 25 years of driving together. Winner of 4 Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Actress. Screenplay by Alfred Uhry based on his play.

results.title: Driving Miss Daisy
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth McBride, Bruno Rubeo, John P. Mesa, Alfred Uhry, Lili Fini Zanuck, Bruce Beresford, Robert Doudell, Richard D. Zanuck, Warner Bros. Pictures, Majestic Films International and The Zanuck Company
results.brief_description: The story of an old Jewish widow named Daisy Werthan and her relationship with her black chauffeur, Hoke. From an initial mere work relationship grew in 25 years a strong friendship between the two very different characters in a time when those types of relationships where shunned.

results.title: Driving home
results.brief_description:
A child is being driven through a real and imaginary landscape. We experience her subtle turmoil as she tries to make sense of these worlds.
This beautiful animation depicts the sense of disorientation and isolation felt by a young girl who is a recent immigrant of Australia. The quintessentially Australian backdrop of the wide open road serves to add to her mental and physical unease. The emotional confusion that is expressed in the narrative is realised perfectly in the shifting, sweeping motion of the oil paint animation. MIFF 2000
